description.narrative: UN-Habitat works directly with local governments and their partners to provide training, tools and guidance for greater resilience of cities. The principle fruit of our work with local governments is a set of Actions for Resilience recommendations tailored to the urban context. The City Resilience Profiling Tool (CRPT) is UN-Habitat´s most extensive tool and follows a people-centered holistic approach to analyse the entire city from a resilience perspective. The methodology allows effective implementation of the New Urban Agenda at local level and works towards the achievement of the SDGs.UN-Habitat also takes a lead role in establishing platforms to foster partnerships and mainstream resilience principles and practices. This includes the Global Alliance for Urban Crisis, a multi-stakeholder constituency-based partnership, geared towards improving the way we prevent, prepar and respond to urban crises.Lastly, the UN-Habitat´s Urban Resilience Programme is a global lab on research and capacity building on resilience. This is generating new findings on urban resilience, the basis of the biennial flagship publication Trends in Urban Resilience which will next be published in 2019. Support is required for research, and later for the promotion of the report´s findings.The support of Norway will contribute to scalling-up the City resilience Profiling Tool from pilot cities to a broader scope of cities. Preparatory work is needed so that by 2019, UN-Habitat can support implementation of CRPT in +20 cities, laready targeted by the Making Resilient Cities Campaign of UN-ISDR. The methodology is expected to scale up to 200 cities by 2030. To make this possible, UN-Habitat is bridging bilateral alliances with local governments with additional support from international organizations, development financial institutions and the private sector.Norway´s support will be extremely important for advocay afforts an mainstreaming urban resilience principles to be discussed during the Barcelona Resilience Week in December 2018. Support is also required to ensure sustainability of the innovative Urban Resilience Hub on resilience for the Global Alliance for Urban Crisis.
